  [i]Lethal Weapon 4 [/i]may be one of the most unnecessary Hollywood films ever made. Everything seen here was seen in the previous installments, and Warner Bros. just wanted to make a ton of money. Nevertheless, the fourth installment is highly entertaining, and the chemistry between Danny Glover and Mel Gibson is still there, but this film has no substance in comparison to the others, and is just a residual reminder of how good this franchise once was.

This film, however, does get something that the third installment was missing, and that is the presence of an interesting villain. Like the first two films, this one has two villains that hold interest. Jet Li made his American film debut here as a Chinese mercenary named Wah Sing Ku, and I am very grateful that Jackie Chan turned down the offer to play the role. Chan probably wouldn't be near as threatening as Li, who has the moves to take down Glover and Gibson within a few seconds. Kim Chan also gives an enjoyable performance as a Chinatown drug dealer, nicknamed "Uncle Benny," who is working with Ku and the Chinese Triad. Chan is very comical in some of his scenes, particularly one scene in a dentist's office, and he and Li are for more interesting than all of the villains in[i] Lethal Weapon 3[/i].

Channing Gibson's script isn't very high on imperative or intriguing material, but there are some interesing themes that are explored with the Mel Gibson character. In the past films, Gibson's Martin Riggs was seen as suicidal, crazy, on the edge, and reckless. He was nearly unstoppable to all of his adversaries, and he was rarely challenged. He didn't care much about whether he lived or die, but here it is different. He wants to marry girlfriend Lorna (Rene Russo), but he doesn't know how that would affect his love for his deceased wife. Lorna is pregnant with a child, and now Riggs has a lot more to loose. We are also seeing that Riggs is getting older, and like soon to be grand-daddy Murtaugh (Danny Glover), Riggs may simply be "too old for this shit." 

One of the problems with this film is that a lot of the comedy feels forced, though some of it is amusing. Chris Rock joins the cast as Detective Lee Butters, who may have a comedy degree in corronation with his psychology and criminal justice credentials. Joe Pesci is also back as Leo Getz, who doesn't have much of a role in the story until the final moments of the film. He easily becomes an antagonist to Rock's Butters, and Leo figures that he will eventually win over Butters when they have an exchange about shitty cell phone service. While some of the exchanges between Pesci and Rock, as well as Glover and Gibson, are amusing, they often fall flat and feel forced. You know it is a bad sign when Leo Getz starts to become an irritation, and Chris Rock probably has the honor of playing the most annoying character in this series. 

The action scenes in the film are top-notch, and Richard Donner starts the film with plenty of movement. The film begins with Riggs and Murtaugh finding out about Lorna and Rianne's (Traci Wolfe) pregnancy, and that is followed by an explosion with a gas tank. The film then has a gunfire on a ship, and the more interesting action sequences come later in the film. Probably the most volatile scene in the film is when Murtaugh and Riggs are in pursuit of a vehicle, and Riggs finds himself hanging onto plastic from the back of a truck on the freeway. The final confrontation between Ku and Riggs and Murtaugh is top notch, with Ku having the upper-hand despite being out numbered. 

In comparison to the other films, [i]Lethal Weapon 4[/i] doesn't have much of a plot, and the film practically stops three quarters of the way to explain what is going on. Wah Sing Ku is working with Uncle Benny in order to counterfeit Chinese currency, as he has plans to buy back "The Four Fathers" from a Chinese general. The Four Fathers were a group affiliated with the Chinese Triad, and one of the members is the brother of Ku. 

[i]Lethal Weapon 4 [/i]could of been passed, but it does have some enjoyable moments, and Gibson and Glover still have the chemsitry that made them so great in the first film. Though everything here has been seen before, and has been done better, it's still worth it to check this out, and this film offered an alternative in 1998, as the only other highly marketed action film was Michael Bay's ridiculous [i]Armageddon[/i].
